Authors:
Thilini Chethana, Kevin D Hyde, Ruvishika Shehali
Jayawardena
Title: Appressorial interactions with host and their evolution
Keywords:
ancestral character, evolution, host-recognition, hyaline
appressoria, infection process, melanised appressoria,
proto-appressoria
Abstract:
Fungi have evolved diverse strategies to acquire nutrients
from their hosts and are endophytes, saprobes, symbionts or pathogens.
Appressoria have been intensively studied due to their importance in
attaching and breaching the host surface. These specialized infection
structures have evolved into various morpho-types: proto-appressoria,
hyaline appressoria, melanised (dark) appressoria and compound
appressoria. In this review, we discuss the differences in the
formation, differentiation and function of appressoria in fungal groups
with diversified life-strategies. Using DNA sequence information, LSU,
5.8S, SSU and RPB2 gene fragments, we reconstructed the ancestral states
for appressorial types in the main phyla of fungi and fungus-like
organisms, and found hyaline appressoria to be the most ancestral form.
Our analysis estimated proto-appressoria diversification during the
early Mesozoic (209Â–379 MYA), however, the current ancestral analysis
does not establish a strong conclusion regarding their origin. Our data
suggest that these hyaline appressoria diversified into melanised or
compound appressoria, with evidence of adaptive radiation.
